Hiya, Joakim

Thanks for your reply. Hmmm... there's maybe a little 
misint=
erpretation there, yes... I was assuming that it was the same 
person writi=
ng the code and the tests, NOT two different people. 
But I'd got the size =
of the cycle wrong, I think. I'd guessed that 
you'd write tests for everyt=
hing a class does, then code the class to 
suit. But that's not what you're=
 saying, is it...

In your world, you write a test class that just tries to=
 make an 
instance of the real class. But it won't compile, so you make the=
 
class and then the test class does compile, and the test works. 
Then you=
 write a test that tries to run a method, but now the test 
class won't com=
pile again because that method doesn't exist yet. So 
you write the method,=
 and now the test compiles. 
Then you add to that test to say what you expe=
ct the method to 
return, and the test fails. So you write the code in the =
method and 
now the test passes.
And so on, in teeny-tiny steps?

Well, I c=
an now see how this can practically be used! And those rules 
do help to ma=
ke it clearer. Thank you. And thanks for the FIT 
pointer, too...

But, thi=
nking about it, maybe this cold be a problem to work with, 
when you're try=
ing to make a big structure with other developers? 
Because this builds up =
from the bottom quite slowly, if I've 
understood it. Doesn't it take a lon=
g while before it's usable in any 
way?
We're typically making a whole stru=
cture, with DA, DTO, Domain 
object, MVC layer and SOAP service. One of the=
 benefits of using 
Interfaces for us, and making whole classes at a time, =
is that we can 
code the Interface for the DAO and Domain Object, offering =
everything 
we'd need, and use those in the other objects, then fill in the=
 
detail in the actual classes. That way, we can work together on one 
enti=
ty. This would be a bit difficult to do if we built it this way, 
building =
up bit by bit from the bottom, wouldn't it?

Or maybe I need to think about=
this some more...

Cheers
Tracey
